title: Data Mining at NASA: from Theory to Applications
segmentation: Thanks Kamal for inviting me to speak today and thank all of you for your participation this afternoon.

Today I'm going to be talking to you about work that's going on at NASA in the field of data mining, and I'll give you a little forewarning that, as you might expect, it's quite different than what most of this conference has been concerning.
Here, we're going to be talking about engineering systems.

And about one specific thread of research that is going on at NASA that I thought might be of interest to you all and also gives you some flavor of the variety both the breadth as well as the depth of work going on in our research program.
So I have two rolls at NASA.
I lead the data mining group and it consists of a team of members about 14.
People are so 20.
If you include student include students.
I also lead the Ivy HM Project.

The Integrated Vehicle Health Management project and this is a project in the Aviation Safety program that is within NASA that really has a large charter to develop new technologies to help commercial aircraft.
That will be existing 5 to 10 years from now.
Become more safe so it's a it's part of the NASA Aviation Safety Program, and I'll be talking to you about that at the very end as a little bit of a insight into what's going on there.
So the intelligent Data understanding group as we call it develops novel novel algorithms to detect, classify, and predict events in large data streams from scientific and engineering systems.
I'd like you to take a look at this chart down here.
It gives it gives you kind of a flavor of some of the things we worry about.
This chart is the output of one of our our anomaly detection systems, called IMS is a system which has been certified to actually be used on the International Space Station.
So as the data is to limit are down from the International Space Station.
It comes through our algorithm and people at Johnson Space Center look at the output of the algorithm to determine whether or not there's a problem on the station or not.
And I tell you, it's fascinating.

We can see when the extra when the astronauts are exercising up there when they're using the exercise machines and so forth because of the patterns that induces in the vibration of the International Space Station.
So this slide up here on the right hand side shows the output of the IMS system.
This anomaly detector.
For a certain part of the International Space Station, the earlier the external Thermal Control system, what happened in January 2007?
Is this developed?
An ammonia gas bubble?
And as that bubble came into play and if you haven't guessed that's a bad thing.
As this ammonia bubble started to develop, the question is can you detect it early enough to stop it?
Otherwise it could cause problems in the future system.
So what we see here is the growth of the anomaly detector with some multivariate time series that's coming into this sometimes between 6 and 100 dimensions.
To give you an idea of the nature of the data we're dealing with, it's continuous data all being to limiter down to our system.
The IMS system starts to detect it that first arrow over there.
Is there a pointer come on?

It starts to detect it that first arrow over there some sort of aberrant behavior, and that starts to grow with time and you can see here towards the end it actually grows very high, indicating that the ammonia bubble bursts.

Now what's interesting about this is that the anomaly detection algorithms that we built detected the event six days prior to the detection via standard techniques, and this is a story that we're going to hear again and again through.

This presentation that the algorithms that we're developing are really trying to do early warning of some sort of a problem that's coming up both in the safety domain and the aviation safety domain, but also here in this space system we're trying to develop these algorithms so that they can do early detection.
This is a great example of that.
On the left hand side you see a chart that I'll be describing a little bit later.
Also that talks about another key problem that we're facing and that is.

Dealing with computational time and storage time because we need to be able to make decisions quickly and rapidly, particularly in scientific domains or engineering domains where those decisions need to go into a real time system real time for us means something like a few milliseconds or less.
One of the projects that we deal with in our in our group is to develop the abort system for the next launch vehicle.
That's going to be used by NASA to take people up into space, and it has.
An interesting set of requirements.
Number 10.
False positives numbers 20.
False negatives.
Has to be 100% correct and on top of that you have to make the decision within 2 seconds and what's the decision?
The decision is whether or not to abort the mission, which means 2.
Eject the crew out of the vehicle far enough away so that when the vehicle explodes, they're not hurt.
That's one of the problems that some members of my team were working on South the safety criticality in the computational time.
Is fast not too.
In order to make sure that we're maintaining a good deal of safety margin for the astronauts, so on the left hand side you'll see a chart which is kind of interesting to me.
It has number of training points on the X axis.
I'm not going to tell you what the computation is just yet.
Number of training points on the X axis on the Y axis we have the time complexity and you can see that the blue dots go up very quickly.
In fact, at about 200 points or so for this, which is frankly for all of us a very very small data set between 2 and 500 points.
It takes 500 seconds to do this calculation.
It's a Gaussian process calculation for regression problem.

We developed methods with our collaborators at San Jose State University that can take this all the way out to a million points in about 20% of the time, and this is the sort of innovation that we're really looking for within NASA so that we can do quick computations.
In essence, we're inverting a matrix of a size 1,000,000 by a million in about 20 seconds on a cheap laptop.
So key areas of research and data mining include anomaly detection.
I've talked to a little bit about.
But already predicting systems looking into the future and trying to determine whether or not we can assess the city state of the vehicle, the state of a spacecraft, things like that, text mining.
It's a big area of work.
In fact, we have a book coming out with good collaborator of ours from.
Google and he moved to Stanford, Maryland, Sami and I edited a book on text mining that's that should be out shortly.

Mining distributed data systems and sensor networks is a big area of research for us in our work and then high performance Time Series Search partnership with Google that I'll mention a little bit later.
Application areas, safety critical systems, large scale distributed systems, the Earth and the space Sciences.
Understanding climate change the drivers behind it and what some of the anomalies might be in the future.
Space science, I'll talk to you in detail about that in a moment, but essentially a phrase that I love to use.
Characterizing the large scale structure of the universe is a project that we work on systems health data from aeronautical and space applications.
This gives you an idea of some of the breadth of the work that's going on.
I don't need to talk to this group of.
Big datasets, but we definitely do have large datasets.
These are some statistics that I pulled a while back that shows.
How fast some of these systems that we're building are generating data.
21 terabytes of data per week from the Earth Observing System.
Right now we're scoping out a 1 1/2 petabyte initial size for an Earth science application that we're going to be building.
And all of this data requires mining and all of you interested in fields where you would like to study large datasets with complex physical relationships in them.
In other words, those relationships that come from.
Physical or natural systems.
These are wonderful to work with aeronautical systems we developed.
A few years ago, a distributed archive that includes about 2 million flights of data from commercial airliners in the United States.
This essentially when you take an airplane flight within the United States.
If it's one of the participating carriers, that data goes into an archive that we built that we can mine in a distributed fashion to look for safety anomalies.
So.
The thread that I'm going to discuss today since so many things go on in the group.

I thought I would pick one thing called virtual sensors, which would be of interest to you and you'll see this one idea how it plays in the earth Sciences in the space Sciences and aeronautics, and finally on the Space Shuttle.
So it's a single thread of research that I can take you through that has kind of an interesting idea, at least in my opinion behind it.
So imagine that you've got a sensor system of some sort, and the system is measuring.
Let's just say, like in May.
Picture in the upper right hand corner it's measuring the state of radiation.
Luminescent radiation from the Earth over a certain part of the Earth, let's say over Greenland for instance, and so you're measuring the luminosity from there in multiple spectral bands.
OK, so this is the basic idea.
And you want to know what those spectral bands would be if you could only measure a subset of that of those bands?
Now here's the reason for that.
It turns out that many times we've got instruments in space which have the ability to measure in certain spectral bands.
Let's say five of them.

Those have been around for a long time, but you have another measurement system which has been around for a short period of time that's measured in 10 spectral dance and you want to figure out GF for that older instrument.
If I could figure out what those five remaining spectral bands are, it would be very useful and I'll show you an example of that.
This is the idea of a virtual sensor that you exploit.
The correlation between the existing known data streams in order to understand what unknown streams might look like.
That's the basic idea, and I've got some equations down here that show essentially what we're trying to do.
You've got sensor measurements, dizzy, and something like wavelength or frequency or something else that is.
Being measured and then also maybe positional information, and from that you want to do predictions and you also want to estimate the uncertainty.
We've as I said, applied this both for the Earth and Space Sciences as well As for Aeronautics and space systems.
And this is a NASA jet that we have.

The lower right hand corner, the F18 down at Dryden Spaceflight Center in the United States that we have as a testbed to explore some of these technologies, and some of our algorithms such as the IMS algorithm, has flown on that aircraft and we have been able to.
Identify and predict certain kinds of anomalies.
So first 1st I'm going to take you through.
Virtual sensors in the earth Sciences.

This is collaboration set we've done over the years with people in within NASA, such as Nick Windows, a Rama, Nemani, Brett Zane Ullman, but also julians trivia who is at the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Boulder, Co.
So here's the idea on the top of this picture.
This is a cartoon.

You see I've got some wiggly lines up there and I've got it as a function of time and there's a specific sensor called the MODIS sensor which is up in space that is measuring let's say 5 spectral bands, and I've labeled them up there in different colors.
But those only go back a few years, let's say from 2005 back to 2000, but I've got this other instrument the a VHR spectral measurement system, which has been up there for many years.
It's been up there for close to 20 years, but you don't have that black line.
You don't have the MODIS cloud signal, and that's an important signal for reasons that I'll describe in a moment.

But you have these other signals available and those of you who look at this, you'll notice that if you could exploit the correlation between those that black signal and the purple line into the blue line and the green line.
If you knew what that correlation was forgiven seen, you should be able to predict what that black line is, and in fact, what you should be able.
To do is build a regression system that takes those data streams that you know in order to predict the unknown data stream and then propagate it back in time.
So it's kind of a backcast if you will.
It's looking back in time to say if I could have measured it, what would it have looked like, so it's a standard idea for people in machine learning or data mining.
You take the existing signals and use exploit the correlation between them and project it back in time.
So if you do that, essentially what happens is that you start to develop a new signal that in this case would be able to tell you what is the state of affairs as far as clouds go.
Or a particular part of the Earth?
So.
We actually went through a process where we built an algorithm to exploit these Inter correlations.
They happen to be nonlinear correlations and then we propagated them back in time.

And here I'm showing you the results for a specific interval in time, about 15 days or so, and you can see on the left hand side of the true positives and on the right hand side the true negatives of this forecasting engine.
Now I'm only showing you 14 days by the way, and I had advertised awhile back that we're going to.
Look back 20 or 30 years.
This is a process that is actually quite challenging and difficult to do because number one.
The data is so large.

But also if we overcome the data problems there's a problem of actually understanding whether or not the numbers that we're observing, whether or not the scenes that we're observing in the predictions that we're making.
Are accurate and what what is challenging about that is today.
It requires human intervention to look to see whether or not they're actually.
Clouds are not clouds in a particular scene, and that takes a remarkable amount of time.
So I'm showing you this for a sample that Julian, our collaborator had studied for us on the upper right hand corner.
Here you'll see that we have for one of the systems that we built using an RBF kernel in a support vector machine.
You'll see that we have a very, very high degree of true positive rate across the time period.
That's this.
This yellow, I'm sorry this red line on the right hand side.

You'll also see that the true negative rate is lower for that same system, but there's another system based on neural networks that's giving us good predictions and then the next stage of this research is to understand how we can combine these sorts of systems together.
These predictions engines in order to make a good prediction, both for the true positive case as well As for the true negative case, and then project that back in time.
So if you look at Greenland itself.
Here I've got 4 pictures, one picture on the upper left hand corner is from the MODIS system.
It's for a specific channel Channel 6 that we're trying to make a prediction for, and you can get an idea from the color variation there of where there are clouds.

This white part on the left hand side indicates some clouds to blue parts also indicate some degree of lack of clouds, and then the red and the other colors indicate different kinds of composition in that part of the earth.
On the remaining 43 screens you see the output of the neural network system.
The support vector machine with an adaptive kernel in it, which I'll describe in a moment, and then the support vector machine with the standard radial basis function kernel init.

This story that comes out of these pictures after we analyzed them in some detail is that the support vector machine with the radial basis function kernel actually does quite a good job of identifying the cloud cover.

But our scientists as we started working with them more and more, became interested in understanding the variation of cloud cover and also the variation of the snow in the snow cover over the area of Greenland.
And what we found is that this adaptive kernel based on the mixture density Mercer kernel that we built.
Actually reveals different kinds of cloud cover, but also different snow cover types over over Greenland, and this was published a few years ago in one of our Journal papers.

Some of the one of the ways that the mixture density Mercer kernel is different than the standard kernel is that it learns the kernel directly from the data based on the probability distributions of the data that's actually observed.
We construct a kernel, submit that into a support vector machine in order to.
In order to make predictions.
Here you can see the application of the model to the AV HRR data on the upper left hand side is the output of the VHR system.

This is a satellite and you can see that there are essentially a lot of clouds over the entire ice surface, whereas with the prediction systems, the multilayer perceptron and the two support vector machines, you can see that there's actually a much better discrimination of cloud cover over here.
Which we have quantified in our pay.
So to summarize, the application to an entire historical record is a significant task because of the data quality issues and the transitions that occur from one sensor system to the other.
We're trying to develop these systems so that we can not only look back in time, but also emulate sensors that don't exist yet, so that if we were to say.
Let's consider building a new sensor system with a new spectral measurement wavelength.
We might be able to make a prediction of what those scenes might show us without actually building it, so this is a great prom.

Us that this sort of research has for us, I'm going to now switch from the Earth Sciences out into space and talk about virtual sensors in astrophysics, and this is work that we're doing with the collaborators at Goddard Institute of Space Science, as well as San Jose State University.
So.
I love this pic.
Because each blue dot up there happens to correspond to a Galaxy.
This is a very, very tiny portion of the of the Sky.
Each blue dot corresponds to a Galaxy, and for some of those those red dots.
Those are galaxies for which we have measured the distance.
From the earth using high resolution Spectra Spectra spectroscopy, which means that we have a very good clear understanding of how far away those galaxies are.
But there are a lot of galaxies up there.
In green.
For which we have.
For which we have broadband data, in other words, it's not precise information about how far away those galaxies are.
Here comes the problem.
We need to be able to build a prediction system that says.
What exactly is the distance of those objects that are in green away from the earth?
And if we can do that, then my cosmology friends say that we would be able to build to the first map of the universe the first 3 dimensional map of the universe.
Right now we know where those galaxies are in 2 dimensions.
As you can see here, but we don't know for most of them what the third dimension is.
This is a beautiful problem.
Given by some of our friends in astrophysics.
So on this chart you can see the kind of information that we have.
These black lines correspond to the spectral emission of 1 Galaxy and you can see that it's very high resolution, and in fact it's so high resolution that you can use it to calculate the redshift.
And if you remember back to your physics class is essentially what happens to due to the Doppler effect.
Is that the spectral lines get shifted and based on the amount they get shifted as well as certain other physical principles.
You can calculate how far away these objects are from the Earth, so that's great, but it's extremely expensive to get those black lines.
What's cheaper is to get the lines here in pink and the blue and the.
In the yellow regions and so forth.
These are regions which have our broadband and you can just take a measurement there very easily and get an answer out to say what that Spectra looks like.
But there's a huge loss of information when you go from the black lines to these broadband filters.
And So what we're trying to do is build a system that goes, takes data from these broadband filters, and estimates what the redshift of those galaxies might be.
So Z is a.
Is the number that tells us the redshift of galaxies Z = 0 means that the Galaxy is very close to us.
1.1 is very far away and you can see how the shift occurs and the nature of the.
Data that we're getting.
So in order to address this problem.
We studied a number of approaches, one of them that I'm going to be discussing here in detail is Gaussian process regression.
And before I move on, I'd like to point out again the thread that I to the virtual sensor idea.
Here again, we have two sensor systems.
One of the sensor systems is very high Fidelity, the other one is not.
We want to emulate the high Fidelity one using low Fidelity measure measurements.
So that's the common thread between this and the previous area.
I'm sure many of you know about Gaussian process regression.
I won't go into it in great detail other than to say that it's a very expensive computation.
It requires a lot of memory order of N squared memory and time computation is order of N cubed in terms of computational complexity.
Which is fine if you have a few 100 or a few thousand points.
But when you start scaling up to millions or billions of points, that certainly doesn't work.

But what we're finding through our empirical studies is that as we scale larger and larger, we're getting better and better answers, and so we wanted to figure out a way of building these Gaussian processes and executing them quickly without enduring a lot of computational cost.
So the standard least squares problem is shown here.
Essentially what you want to do is minimize the norm between the prediction values.
Why the targets play I should say and the predictions?
8 * X and I'm just showing you this to set up the problem for Gaussian process regression.
Obviously if you take the derivative, set it equal to 0, you get out the normal equations which are shown here, and there are many ways to solve these quickly and efficiently.
You can do QR factorization, many other methods.
Order to get the answer quickly and numerically, effectively.

For the kernel methods, there's something called subset of regressors which was developed by Grace Wahba and her team in 1990, and this is the governing equation for it and what I'd like you to notice here is that it's very similar to the least squares solution.
In fact, if you set Lambda equal to 0, it looks a lot like least squares problems, which is what you would expect again.

Here, though, the memory requirements is order of N * M. And the time complexity is order of M * M ^2, which means that we're getting quite a bit of reduction in the total amount of time and memory requirement.
But there's a question with the numerical stability, and so our.
Collaborator Leslie Foster at San Jose State University.
We started to work with them on developing a cure for this numerical instability, which he called the V method.
So here's the way it works.
From your kernel method you select columns to make K well conditioned case.

The kernel matrix that comes from the kernel function that you've chosen to be well conditioned and then use a stable technique for least squares problem such as the QR factorization or the so called V method with the requirement that we maintain order of N * M memory use and M squared in terms of efficiency.
So the way this proceeds is that you use Cholesky factorization with pivoting.
So partially factor K. Select the appropriate columns for K. After you've done that.
Factorization and then you can show the paper shows that we have that this new matrix will be well conditioned and will also be of low enough rank that you'll be able to do.

Calculations quickly, so the way this proceeds then is that your kernel function or your kernel matrix K is now written as the product of two matrices, where V is now one of the factorizations that come out of the out of the method that I described before.
Via this rescaling of a well conditioned matrix, and it's also then we can show that it's numerically stable and it can be much faster and need much less.
Memory, then one needs before using the older methods.
So if you take these this method and apply it to the real world data here, what you get in fact on the X axis.
I've plotted the RMS error on the Y axis is is the number of cases that fall into that level of RMS errors.
So this is like a histogram.
Essentially what you see here is that the Gaussian process regression and the some other models here do reasonably well.
The unfortunate part of this chart is that we need to get about 10 times better.
In terms of accuracy, in order to make a good and effective map of the universe, so we're still quite quite far away from doing that.
What we're trying to do right now is scale up this system so that it can deal with on the org.
Of a million galaxies and beyond.
And here are some of the scalability results on the X axis.
You can see the size of the training set that we're using, and on the Y axis the calculation time.
The old methods essentially show chart that goes up very rapidly.
There are infeasible for use in the datasets that we're working with.
The lines at the bottom of the chart in pink are essentially showing the computational time using the V method, and you can see that they are extremely efficient in terms of computation time.
Essentially close to 0 even all the way out to using 150,000 galaxies again on a relatively inexpensive laptop, we have large computer clusters.
Now, with this technology we can start to implement it as you would all do on a cluster in order to scale this up to millions and millions of points so you can see that.
The initial technology was built and it's extremely effective in both computational time as well as in terms of accuracy.

The results that we've gotten here, to the best of our knowledge are the best published results in terms of the accuracy of the prediction of the redshifts, and I'm showing you some charts here that essentially showed that the.
The method that was developed, the subset of Regressors method with the V formulation that I described briefly earlier, has lowest arm RMS error for these datasets.
You can see on the lower right hand corner for instance, and also the lowest computational time.
So really for the first time we're seeing here that these methods might allow us to scale up to large datasets.

The unfortunate thing that I mentioned earlier, though, is still we need to be about a factor of 10 in terms of improvement in terms of the accuracy in order to properly characterize large scale structure of the universe.
So.
The work was.

Published recently in the Journal of Machine Learning Research and we also have data available in case anybody is interested, were in fact thinking of starting a competition on this subject that we might be running later.
Next year.
So.
We've talked about the Earth Sciences, virtual sensors, space Sciences, virtual sensors.
Now I'm going to move into a third area, which is probably more exciting in terms of the actual impact that it has on real world missions.

Within NASA, so in the NASA world, probably the most coveted activity is to be part of the so-called Flight Readiness Review, and this is the time when all of the engineers and scientists with the NASA that working on the space shuttle get together and say, should we launch, or should we not launch?
And that's the question at the end of the day, they need to answer that question clearly.
And essentially with absolutely no concern.
That there will be a problem.
So Valentine's Day.
Of this year I got a phone call.
It happened to be a Saturday.

I got a phone call from Kennedy Space Center saying would you join the Flight Readiness review and be the data mining expert in order to help us determine whether or not the shuttle should fly later on.
And obviously I said yes even.
It was Valentine's Day, much to the chagrin of my wife.
I should point out, so the request came in and we were asked to determine whether or not we could use data mining techniques to determine whether or not a certain crack a curd.
In the flow control valve of the Space Shuttle main engine, so the main engine is an extremely complicated system.
As you'd imagine there's a specific part of it called the flow control valve, which is pictured here, and if you look at it closely, it's actually broken.
So.
This region here.
In White is actually the reflection from the flash showing the breakage that occurred on the flight of the shuttle in November 2008.
And so this was noted during the flight and then they said, can we determine whether or not this is a curd before?
Can we determine whether or not data mining and machine learning techniques could have detected that particular failure that occurred at the time?
So we brought out our algorithms, the MSL group?
Which I described briefly earlier.
Which essentially looks says that a data point is anomalous if it is far away from clusters of nominal points.

Oracle which was presented here at KDD a few years ago says that a data point is anomalous if it is far away from its nearest neighbors virtual sensors, which again, is that I that I'm going to make in a few moments.
The data that we had was relatively low dimensional, 13 pressure temperature measurements and control variables related to the flow control valve subsystem of the Space Shuttle main engine.
We started to build the South end and start looking at more and more parameters.
In fact have done.
A lot of analysis on the Space Shuttle main engine using techniques that I'm describing here.
So.
The IMS score shows is shown here on the X axis you have time on.
the Y axis is the distance of the observed points from clusters that the IMS system had discovered on nominal data, and what you can see for this particular flight STS.
Essentially other than the transients that occur during lunch.
Of the shuttle, it's pretty flat, which is good news, which means that there is.
Nothing going on.
Now when you look at the data set from S TS 126 which was launched that occurred in November, which had that crack that I was describing, you see something pretty different.
Here you see that between 0 and 60 seconds there is a lot of transients.
And then at 90 seconds actually 93.6 seconds.
That anomaly score jumps up and it persists for the rest of the flight.
And when we saw this, we knew that we had discovered the time at which that cracker Curd.
In fact, after going around with the engineers at Kennedy, as well as the Johnson Space Center, it became clear that IMS was detecting that failure in the space Shuttle flow control valve.
And you can see here that there's an oscillation that's occurring.
Through that time that corresponds to times of which the valves are being turned on and turned off by the main compute.
In the Space Shuttle main engine we can breakdown that signal that anomaly signal into its subcomponents to figure out what part of the engine was actually.
Misfiring or causing the problem?

And when you do that, you see that the blue line is on top and the blue line corresponds to to the exact location of that valve that had broken and you can see that of all of the anomaly scores, it's the highest.
And if you're interested in IMS, I haven't described the underlying algorithm here, but we have a number of publications out on that particular algorithm.
Suffice it to say, the bigger the number, the further it is away from zero.
More anomalous, the score is.
So.
We decided to build a virtual sensor for this.
In other words, this sensor is now taking data from the rest of the shuttle.
Sorry, the rest of the main propulsion system and predicting what should be the correct value for the pressure in this particular part of the engine.
Now when you look at a nominal normal flight, here STS 118 on the top, essentially the entire data stream stays within.
The red lines and what this means is that the virtual sensor prediction and what's actually observed are very close, which is great news.
Essentially all of the data looks normal.
Now when you look at STS 126, that's the nominal the off nominal flight.
You see again at 93.6 seconds sharp rise in the anomaly score, which persists for the rest of the flight, and what this told us is that at that particular time, again a failure occurred.
So we.
When we presented this when I presented this to the Flight Readiness Review Committee, they said, Oh yeah, but you know there are all these other things.
In fact, one of the astronauts who's on the committee said what's going on before 93 seconds.
And remember earlier I said those are transients.
Let's not worry about it because essentially, between zero and eight minutes out the shuttle goes from stationary to Mach 17 or so in terms of speed.
So somebody like me says there are transients.
Let's not worry about it.
The astronaut, however, who's flying on him, says maybe we should look at the transients and determined but not actually came down much more strongly than I have described it just now.
So so we.
So we dutifully looked into it, and we found in fact, that many of the things early on are in fact transients.
They are occurring at the time when the throttle of the shuttle is going from low to high and low.
It's actually very difficult.

Turns out to get something into space, particularly the size of the shuttle because of something called Max Q, which is the time when the shuttle is at maximum aerodynamic pressure, and so if you go through it to fall faster and properly, you could actually destroy the craft and so at that time they actually reduce the throttle level so that it can pass through that transition period.
Increase the throttle in order to put it into orbit.
So that's what's happening.

At various times in this transient area, the particular blips that are occurring before and after 50 seconds, we were able to isolate are due to particular transitions that are occurring in that particular flight due to some of the control variables.
So we were able to resolve it.
We gave our recommendation of the Flight Review Committee that this issue has been resolved and that we can in fact detect these sorts of events after this.
Readiness Review is complete.
I don't want to indicate that it was only whingeing on our information.
Lots of people around NASA were working on this problem.
The entire committee then voted yes.
In fact, launch and then in March of this year the launch occurred and it went off without a hitch.
So.
We decided to investigate that transient.
A little bit more by developing what we called adaptive thresholds, and this has been.
This is I should say, been submitted to a Journal.

Will see if it gets published, but the idea of the adaptive threshold is to use an ensemble model to assess at any given time point what the exact what to estimate the uncertainty in the predictions that we're making.
The higher the uncertainty we could say if there's a large vote that's uncertain, you could say.
This is probably due to transients in the data, probably not something due to a real phenomenon in the system.

Increase the throttle in order to put it into orbit.

In the data mining community and apply it in the role of improving.

Aviation safety within the United States, but a lot of the work that we do is actually used worldwide, so I lead a relatively large project in aviation safety called integrated Vehicle Health management and what this project is concerned with is developing technologies that can help detect, diagnose, predict, and mitigate adverse events during the flight of a large commercial transport aircraft.
Not today's aircraft, but the aircraft that will exist 5 to 10 years from now.
We work very closely with Boeing, Honeywell, another major major units, major corporations that are working in this field as well as with academia.
As you'll see in a moment, in order to develop these technologies, this is much bigger than data mining.
